Top launches include the following:

+ Launching the product in 20+ new languages and introducing currency selection for international users

Experience Associate Product Manager Google (Android) August 2014  – Present (1 year) Mountain View, California Led feature development, established roadmaps for app engineering team, and coordinated across UX design, marketing, PR, legal, and release teams through 4 launches of Google News for Android and 4 core system apps on Nexus, Android One, and Android Wear. 
 
During this time News increased its Android user base 2x to over 80 million, and its Play Store rating held at a consistently high 4.1, trending slightly upward. 
 
Established internal quality standards for Android apps and led 17 teams across Google to unpublish their apps from the Play Store. 
 
Created and implemented an OEM ecosystem strategy for Android Open Source Project (AOSP) app development across Google. Associate Product Manager Google (Maps) July 2013  –  July 2014  (1 year 1 month) New York, New York Analyzed Google's local listings data to identify areas on which to focus data quality efforts.  
 
Proposed improvements to algorithms and operator workflows which reduced costs while either maintaining or increasing data quality. 
 
Interviewed 20+ APM candidates, gave recruiting presentations at Dartmouth and Cornell, and organized the NYC office’s first APM alum talk. Editor Brown Journal of World Affairs September 2011  –  May 2013  (1 year 9 months) Providence, Rhode Island Editor for a foreign policy journal whose contributors include current and former heads of state, diplomats, and Nobel Prize winners. 
 
Solicited politicians, academics, and activists around the globe; edited the content and grammar of their articles for the global warming section and the essays section; helped lay out the print edition of each issue using Adobe InDesign. 
 
Proposed the section on drone warfare in issue 19.2, and led a team of 4 editors through solicitation and editing for that section. Resolved UX design and legal issues.

Summary I want to summarize content on the web (it's easy to discover information - thanks search engines - now how do I myself parse it all?) and by extension, I want to impact educational tech and make it possible for people to take all their fragments of time and turn it into productive learning/creating/ideation time. The research that I'm doing in the MIT Media Lab is tackling an interesting take on this idea: how we can use software to help us learn more, augment creativity, and produce better output? These types of questions all center around the field of intelligence augmentation. 
 
A long term goal I'd be interested in solving is how we can intelligently generate education modules (in subjects such as math) that kids can progress through at their own pace, rather than following an arbitrarily defined and scientifically unsupported schedule of topics written by policy makers and administrators. 
 
My two intended fields of exploration lie in product management and strategy consulting in the tech industry. My background in CS helps keep me grounded though, because sometimes all you need are some tangible diffs and a really good playlist.
